abstract: Cleanup crews with Suncor Energy were trying to contain a small spill near a Denver-area oil refinery on Wednesday after liquid began seeping into a creek this week.
snippet: Cleanup crews with Suncor Energy were trying to contain a small spill near a Denver-area oil refinery on Wednesday after liquid began seeping into a creek this week.
lead_paragraph: Cleanup crews with Suncor Energy were trying to contain a small spill near a Denver-area oil refinery on Wednesday after liquid began seeping into a creek this week. Suncor was investigating the source of the leak and what precisely was oozing into the creek near its refinery in Commerce City. Workers were trying to keep the liquid from flowing into the South Platte River. Curtis Kimbel, an Environmental Protection Agency coordinator, described the material as a petroleum-type substance. Workers had contained the spill to an area of about 75 yards, he said. The National Wildlife Federation said it was concerned that the material could contain Canadian oil sands crude, which can be difficult to clean because it is so thick.

headline.main: Colorado: Spill Near Refinery Is Investigated
headline.print_headline: Colorado: Spill Near Refinery Is Investigated

abstract: Grammy nominees are announced, Fox News and debates replace retail campaigning and Time Inc. appoints a digital advertising executive as its chief.

lead_paragraph: The rapper Kanye West received the most nominations for the 54th Annual Grammy Awards during a ceremony broadcast on Wednesday night on CBS, but it was the pop stars Adele and Bruno Mars who dominated the Song of the Year, Record of the Year and Album of the Year nominations, The ArtsBeat blog reported. Adele, the British soul singer, received six nominations for her album “21,” which included the hit “Rolling in the Deep.” (Her singing voice has been temporarily silenced by vocal cord surgery, and it is not clear, The Los Angeles Times reported, whether Adele will have recovered sufficiently to perform when the awards are handed out on Feb. 12.) Mr. Mars also received six nominations, three for “Grenade,” his song about unrequited love, and three for the album “Doowops and Hooligans.” Mr. West was nominated seven times based on two albums — his complex solo set “My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy” and his collaboration with Jay-Z, “Watch the Throne.” Both were left off the Album of the Year list, but were nominated for Rap Album of the Year. (The snub of MBDTF, as Mr. West’s album is known, was certainly the hot topic on Twitter.)

headline.main: Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 1

lead_paragraph: The Royal Bank of Scotland announced Friday the sale of its British pub chain to the Dutch brewing giant Heineken for £412 million ($646 million). The deal is part of an aggressive sale of noncore assets by the struggling British bank, which is 83 percent owned by the government after receiving a £20 billion bailout in 2008. The bank bought the chain of 918 pubs, known as the Galaxy Pub Estate, in 1999 and 2000, as it looked to expand its operations into property to take advantage of rising prices of British commercial real estate.

lead_paragraph: There have been creeping indications that the magazine business isn’t really about magazines anymore. In 2010, Hearst Magazines bought iCrossing, a digital marketing agency, and the company has since christened publications that have no print version. Every day, my in-box swells with announcements that this or that glossy now has an iPad app, nearly all of them trumpeting “amazing interactive features that take you far beyond a traditional magazine experience.” Over and over we are told that a magazine is really just one vehicle for a brand that scales across platforms.

lead_paragraph: Empires built through acquisitions can run into problems as they sprawl. That’s doubly so in technology, where obsolescence is a risk. Oracle has used profits from its database stronghold to expand. Its acquisitions have worked well so far — that’s one reason its German archrival SAP has become more active itself, buying SuccessFactors for $3.4 billion on Saturday. But the sad experience undergone recently by Cisco Systems suggests that Oracle’s boss, Lawrence Ellison, needs to stay on his toes.

lead_paragraph: The production of “Cloud Atlas,” a film version of the David Mitchell novel that has a $100 million budget, is an example of how sophisticated filmmakers “are turning to a globe-straddling independent finance system for their most expensive projects,” rather than American studios, Nicholas Kulish and Michael Cieply report. The talent connected to the project includes Andy and Lana Wachowski, the American-born team behind the “Matrix” movies, and Tom Hanks and Halle Berry. But investors from China, South Korea, Singapore and beyond contributed roughly $35 million, without which the film could not have been made. German subsidies account for $18 million more.

lead_paragraph: Adam Nagourney writes about Jay Carson and Chris Lehane, two former Democratic operatives in Washington who serve as the models for political consultants in different Hollywood movies. The Carson-inspired character was at the heart of “The Ides of March,” directed by George Clooney; Mr. Lehane is a writer and producer of “Knife Fight,” slated for release early next year, which also focuses on a political consultant. Both worked for President Bill Clinton, Mr. Nagourney writes, and “not surprisingly, each movie has an older male candidate who has sexual relations with an intern.” But more generally, he writes that the movies “go beyond the usual Hollywood glorification of political consultants, offering dark and at times unsettling accounts of what is done in the name of winning elections.”

Latino women account for one in every four subscribers of Cosmopolitan, and the Cosmopolitan Web site will have separate tab for Latino-focused content. abstract: In the first years of the euro, which was introduced in 1999, countries on the edge of the euro zone benefited economically more than Germany. But over the last five years, the situation has been reversed. The charts show data for euro zone countries divided into four groups. Germany and France, the two largest countries, are shown individually. Five Northern Europe economies, which some have speculated could join Germany and France in a new “strong euro” zone, are shown as a group labeled “Northern countries.” The other 10 countries are combined in a group labeled “Peripheral countries.” These include all the countries currently receiving European assistance, as well as Spain, Italy and other countries.

abstract: The maker of telephone equipment said it would not seek new customers in Iran and would limit business activities with existing customers because of the situation there.
snippet: The maker of telephone equipment said it would not seek new customers in Iran and would limit business activities with existing customers because of the situation there.
lead_paragraph: Huawei Technologies, a leading Chinese maker of telecommunications equipment, said it would voluntarily restrict business in Iran because of what it called the “increasingly complex situation” there. In an announcement on its Web site, Huawei said it would not seek new customers in Iran and would limit business activities with existing customers. Huawei, a privately owned company that has been seeking access to the American market, did not elaborate on its reasons for the pullback from Iran, which has become the target of increased sanctions by the United States and the European Union over its disputed nuclear program. Last year, some American lawmakers expressed concern over reports that Huawei had supplied communications technology to Iran and had sold equipment to Iraq during the regime of Saddam Hussein, in violation of United Nations sanctions.

lead_paragraph: The characters in “Game of Thrones,” the HBO series from the fantasy novels of George R. R. Martin, speak Dothraki, a language with more than 3,250 words. Dothraki was created by David J. Peterson, a 30-year-old “conlanger,” a person who constructs new languages. (Of course, even “real” languages are products of invention – for example, my dictionary doesn’t have the world “conlanger.”) The lengths the producers have gone to have a consistent language, Amy Chozick writes, represents Hollywood’s growing need “to infuse fantasy and science-fiction movies, television series and video games with a sense of believability.” It was true for “Avatar,” which included a robust language, Na’vi, that was spoken by the giant blue inhabitants of Pandora. The inventor of Na’vi is developing a Martian language called Barsoomian for “John Carter,” a science-fiction movie from Disney.

abstract: The key to Amazon’s success over the years has been its relentlessness. Most retailers hit a cruising speed and stay there. Amazon, for better or worse, keeps accelerating. Amazon’s millions of customers do not mind its aggressive tactics. Yet.
snippet: The key to Amazon’s success over the years has been its relentlessness. Most retailers hit a cruising speed and stay there. Amazon, for better or worse, keeps accelerating. Amazon’s millions of customers do not mind its aggressive tactics. Yet.
lead_paragraph: If Amazon had a secret agenda in 2011 to fuel a backlash against itself, the retailer has scored another triumph. Its refusal to collect sales tax in California despite a new law compelling it to do so prompted some well-publicized criticism not only from politicians but the tech community. Its hiring of ambulances at its Pennsylvania warehouse to wait for workers to keel over in the summer heat conjured up a Dickensian sweatshop. The retailer apparently brought its Kindle Fire tablet to market before it had all the kinks out, disappointing some of its biggest fans.

headline.main: For Amazon, Lashes and Backlashes

abstract: The online piracy debate heats up in Congress, Nick Kristof gets embedded in jail and the radio host in Iowa that all the candidates must meet.
snippet: The online piracy debate heats up in Congress, Nick Kristof gets embedded in jail and the radio host in Iowa that all the candidates must meet.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, a House committee plans to take up the Stop Online Piracy Act, one of a pair of bills in the Congress intended to curb online piracy, particularly of movies, music and television shows. On one side is the entertainment business, which considers the current tools inadequate to fight pirating sites, “a Whac-a-Mole approach,” Edward Wyatt writes. On the other side, technology companies, who argue that the bills are “so broad and heavy-handed that they threaten to close Web sites and broadband service providers and stifle free speech.” Each is marshaling huge resources to lobby Congress and the American public, with the entertainment business framing the issue as about protecting jobs in the United States.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 15

snippet: The compromise makes small-business assistance available to more — and larger — companies.
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives and the Senate have resolved a three-year battle over the future of two important federal initiatives to aid small businesses: the Small Business Innovation Research program and the Small Business Technology Transfer program. On the particulars, the Senate seems to have carried the day, but the House has won long-term changes to the innovation research program that open it up to companies backed by venture capital. In their dispute, the House and Senate have served as proxies for opposing views of the program’s purpose: whether it should funnel funds to small businesses otherwise neglected by the markets, or maximize the return to the economy in job and wealth creation.

headline.main: Congress Reaches Deal to Reauthorize and Revamp Small-Business Programs

lead_paragraph: Most family businesses don’t survive beyond the founder’s generation. Bari Jay, in its second generation, and Johnson Security Bureau, in its third, are two exceptions. Both companies are thriving largely because of the efforts of two of our business group members, Susan Parker and Jessica Johnson, respectively. Each woman stepped in after her father’s death, and remade aspects of the business, often taking steps that their fathers never would have  considered — or endorsed. During our latest meeting of the group, Ms. Johnson and Ms. Parker talked about what their fathers might think if they were to see how things run today.

abstract: The number of private sector workers who were laid off or discharged over the last 12 months is the lowest for any similar period since the government began collecting the statistics in 1990. The rate of hiring also remains low, but has improved since the recession ended in 2009. The number of workers quitting their jobs — a sign of confidence that they can do better elsewhere — has also risen. The number of job openings relative to the number of unemployed workers is down from the peak, but remains far above prerecession levels.

snippet: Sean Parker, the entrepreneur probably now most famous for being portrayed in the movie “The Social Network,” struggles with his fame. Whether by design or impulse, Mr. Parker, one of the people behind Napster and Facebook, has an almost compulsiv...
lead_paragraph: Over the Thanksgiving holiday, I interviewed Sean Parker, a founder of Napster and a former president of Facebook, for a profile that ran in The New York Times Sunday Style section. Some of the reaction online to the article suggested that Mr. Parker was reminiscent of Steve Jobs, a founder of Apple, who died in October at 56. I believe it is too soon to make that comparison. The next five years are crucial for Mr. Parker, who has yet to prove he is an influential force in Silicon Valley.

lead_paragraph: New voting rules for the Academy Awards could help the movie “Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close,” which will be released in Los Angeles and New York on Christmas and won’t play around the country until next year, Michael Cieply writes. The movie was shut out by Golden Globes voters, who were shown a screening at the beginning of the month; the voters said in interviews with Mr. Cieply that they were sharply divided on the movie, with some hating it, some loving it. That kind of polarity didn’t work at the Golden Globes, but it might now prove an advantage in the Oscar contest after changes in balloting for best picture have put a premium on first-place votes.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 20

abstract: Lowe’s pulled its advertising from TLC’s “All American Muslin” to quiet a controversy. And promptly found themselves in the midst of a far bigger one.
snippet: Lowe’s pulled its advertising from TLC’s “All American Muslin” to quiet a controversy. And promptly found themselves in the midst of a far bigger one.
lead_paragraph: Poor Lowe’s. The do-it-yourself chain made room in their budget for TLC’s “All-American Muslim,” a reality show about life in the Muslim American community in Dearborn, Mich., but the company ended up catching some focus for supporting a show that depicted Muslims as something besides terrorists. As it turned out, the protest was hardly broad based, with most of it coming from one guy. Still, the Florida Family Association, as David Caton’s Web site is called, claimed 65 companies agreed to stop advertising on “All-America Muslim.” That didn’t turn out to be precisely true.

headline.main: Tolerance for Intolerance Bruises Lowe’s

snippet: For one editor, life after Vogue; Deadspin on the abuse accusations against a Philadelphia sportswriter; will socially conscious hip-hop make a comeback?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a busy year for Carine Roitfeld, who was replaced last December as the powerful editor of French Vogue by a former friend, Emmanuelle Alt. There have been wild parties she has hosted, fashion magazines and ads she has collaborated on, and talk of starting a new magazine. Ms. Roitfeld, Eric Wilson writes, “has taken every opportunity to demonstrate the value of her brand, post-Vogue,” and concludes: “Rarely has the stock price of a fashion figure shown such resilience, after taking a severe blow to the side, since Lady Duff-Gordon survived the sinking of the Titanic.”

abstract: Kroger, Safeway and Walgreen joined retailers removing Enfamil Premium Newborn formula from stores as regulators tested whether the product caused the death of a newborn.
snippet: Kroger, Safeway and Walgreen joined retailers removing Enfamil Premium Newborn formula from stores as regulators tested whether the product caused the death of a newborn.
lead_paragraph: Kroger, Safeway and Walgreen joined retailers removing Enfamil Premium Newborn formula from stores as regulators tested whether the product caused the death of a newborn. Mead Johnson’s stock fell 5.1 percent to $65.29, after plunging 10 percent on Thursday when Walmart pulled the formula. Supervalu also has withdrawn the formula, a spokesman said. Officials screening samples of the formula and water used to prepare it said results might not come until next week. The newborn tested positive for Cronobacter sakazakii, an environmental bacterium that can be fatal. Another child infected with the bacterium in Missouri had also been given formula, though officials said on Friday that the baby, who survived, ingested other types of products as well. The brand of formula given to the second baby was not disclosed.

headline.main: More Retailers Pull Formula From Shelves

lead_paragraph: The signs of social change were everywhere to see in 2011, and new-media tools were instrumental to that change, whether in Cairo or Lower Manhattan’s Zuccotti Park. But as Bruce Headlam, The Times’s media editor, David Carr, and the Media Equation columnist, discussed this week in a video recap of the year, the business of media didn’t change quite as quickly. But, there’s always next year.

abstract: “Mondo Agnelli,” a new book, tells the story of the Italian industrialist Gianni Agnelli, the struggles and the turnaround of his family’s crown jewel, Fiat, and the rescue of Chrysler.
snippet: “Mondo Agnelli,” a new book, tells the story of the Italian industrialist Gianni Agnelli, the struggles and the turnaround of his family’s crown jewel, Fiat, and the rescue of Chrysler.
lead_paragraph: NINE times out of 10, it’s possible to predict the quality of narrative books, especially those set in the business world, even before the author sits down and begins writing — even before the first interview is secure in a tape recorder. It’s not the idea or the specific angle that is the giveaway. Sad to say, it’s the access.

headline.main: Fiat’s Rough Road, and Its Renewal
